llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: Introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The GraphQL response returns validation errors that reveal schema-level information. Specifically, the message exposing that the 'post' field requires an argument 'id' of type 'ID!' discloses field names and argument types. The errors referencing 'queryType' and 'types' indicate attempts to use introspection-related fields and show how the server responds to such queries. This is an information-disclosure / introspection issue because an attacker can use these errors to enumerate schema structure (field names, required arguments and types), aiding automated discovery and targeted attacks. Mitigation: suppress or normalize error messages, disable introspection in production, or restrict introspection to authenticated/authorized users.", "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"queryType\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\".\", \"Cannot query field \\\"types\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\".\", \"Field \\\"post\\\" argument \\\"id\\\" of type \\\"ID!\\\" is required, but it was not provided.\"", "confidence": 0.8, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "Introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.8, "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"queryType\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\".\", \"Cannot query field \\\"types\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\".\", \"Field \\\"post\\\" argument \\\"id\\\" of type \\\"ID!\\\" is required, but it was not provided.\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response returns validation errors that reveal schema-level information. Specifically, the message exposing that the 'post' field requires an argument 'id' of type 'ID!' discloses field names and argument types. The errors referencing 'queryType' and 'types' indicate attempts to use introspection-related fields and show how the server responds to such queries. This is an information-disclosure / introspection issue because an attacker can use these errors to enumerate schema structure (field names, required arguments and types), aiding automated discovery and targeted attacks. Mitigation: suppress or normalize error messages, disable introspection in production, or restrict introspection to authenticated/authorized users."}}]

llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL response reveals schema-level information and suggestions. The 'Did you mean \"title\"?' message and the explicit statements about unknown arguments and required argument types leak field names, argument names, and types. This aids an attacker in enumerating the schema and crafting targeted queries (reconnaissance), increasing the likelihood of further exploitation. Recommended mitigations: disable detailed GraphQL validation/suggestion messages in production, return generic error responses, turn off debug mode, and restrict schema introspection or enforce access controls on introspection and error output.", "evidence": "Error messages in response: \"Cannot query field \\\"tittle\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\"; \"Unknown argument \\\"input\\\" on field \\\"Query.post\\\".\"; \"Field \\\"post\\\" argument \\\"id\\\" of type \\\"ID!\\\" is required, but it was not provided.\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error messages in response: \"Cannot query field \\\"tittle\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\"; \"Unknown argument \\\"input\\\" on field \\\"Query.post\\\".\"; \"Field \\\"post\\\" argument \\\"id\\\" of type \\\"ID!\\\" is required, but it was not provided.\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL response reveals schema-level information and suggestions. The 'Did you mean \"title\"?' message and the explicit statements about unknown arguments and required argument types leak field names, argument names, and types. This aids an attacker in enumerating the schema and crafting targeted queries (reconnaissance), increasing the likelihood of further exploitation. Recommended mitigations: disable detailed GraphQL validation/suggestion messages in production, return generic error responses, turn off debug mode, and restrict schema introspection or enforce access controls on introspection and error output."}}]

[{"detection_name": "LLM: introspection", "detection": "potential", "category": "Injection Attacks", "description": "The response contains a '__type' object listing the 'Post' type and its fields (id, title, body, user, comments). This is direct evidence that GraphQL introspection is available and returning schema metadata. Introspection enabled in production can allow attackers to enumerate types, fields and relationships, making it easier to discover sensitive fields and craft targeted queries or find authorization gaps. No other explicit injection or execution errors were observed in the provided response. Recommended mitigations: disable introspection in production or restrict it to authenticated/authorized users, implement query complexity/depth limits and proper field-level authorization checks.", "evidence": "\"__type\": { \"name\": \"Post\", \"fields\": [ { \"name\": \"id\" }, { \"name\": \"title\" }, { \"name\": \"body\" }, { \"name\": \"user\" }, { \"name\": \"comments\" } ] }", "confidence": 0.9, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "introspection", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.9, "evidence": "\"__type\": { \"name\": \"Post\", \"fields\": [ { \"name\": \"id\" }, { \"name\": \"title\" }, { \"name\": \"body\" }, { \"name\": \"user\" }, { \"name\": \"comments\" } ] }", "explanation": "The response contains a '__type' object listing the 'Post' type and its fields (id, title, body, user, comments). This is direct evidence that GraphQL introspection is available and returning schema metadata. Introspection enabled in production can allow attackers to enumerate types, fields and relationships, making it easier to discover sensitive fields and craft targeted queries or find authorization gaps. No other explicit injection or execution errors were observed in the provided response. Recommended mitigations: disable introspection in production or restrict it to authenticated/authorized users, implement query complexity/depth limits and proper field-level authorization checks."}}]

llm_results: [{"detection_name": "LLM: field_suggestions", "detection": "potential", "category": "Unknown", "description": "The GraphQL error responses explicitly suggest correct field names (e.g., 'Did you mean \"title\"?'). This leaks schema information (valid type and field names), which allows an attacker to enumerate or infer the API schema and craft targeted queries to discover sensitive data. While not an injection or direct data leak by itself, field suggestion output increases the attack surface and can facilitate further attacks (data enumeration, authorization probing). Recommend disabling or suppressing field suggestions and returning generic validation errors in production, or restrict verbose errors to authenticated/privileged users.", "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"titl\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\", \"Cannot query field \\\"bodyy\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"body\\\"?\", \"Cannot query field \\\"namee\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"name\\\"?\"", "confidence": 0.95, "llm_analysis": {"is_vulnerable": true, "vulnerability_type": "field_suggestions", "severity": "MEDIUM", "confidence": 0.95, "evidence": "Error messages: \"Cannot query field \\\"titl\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"title\\\"?\", \"Cannot query field \\\"bodyy\\\" on type \\\"Post\\\". Did you mean \\\"body\\\"?\", \"Cannot query field \\\"namee\\\" on type \\\"User\\\". Did you mean \\\"name\\\"?\"", "explanation": "The GraphQL error responses explicitly suggest correct field names (e.g., 'Did you mean \"title\"?'). This leaks schema information (valid type and field names), which allows an attacker to enumerate or infer the API schema and craft targeted queries to discover sensitive data. While not an injection or direct data leak by itself, field suggestion output increases the attack surface and can facilitate further attacks (data enumeration, authorization probing). Recommend disabling or suppressing field suggestions and returning generic validation errors in production, or restrict verbose errors to authenticated/privileged users."}}]
